q: fully splendid only by means of all the lines after it; if you went back to it you would find it less splendid than you thought. you would kill it. i mean in a good poem. <q>( 75) the beauty of literature( and, in a broader scheme, art) lies in its unfolding. the reader is kept unaware of the ultimate destination purposely; otherwise, there would be no force driving the motivation forward, no process to undergo. appreciation of art lies in the same process. art that exists </q> inseparably bound to the qualities of things, yet distinctly itself "must possess some lasting element that draws the subject further and further along without reaching a definitive climax( oury, p. 4). in perelandra,
